Posts.Content: Aloha Tre, I read with interest about rebounding. Do you think it would be beneficial for someone 4 years out of surgery? The tissue seems to get tougher and tougher as time goes on. Thanks for your input. On 10/4/2008 trehouse60 wrote: Hi Courtney, While you are deciding what to do, you might try using a rebounder (mini-trampoline) to start getting that scar tissue softened up and more mobile. You can get a 36" mini-trampoline for around $30 - 40 at discount stores like Target and Walmart, and online. Don't spend a lot of money on it - the inexpensive ones are just as good. Just make sure if you are a heavy woman that it is rated for your weight.  (Mine can handle up to 250# - is a good incentive for me to keep exercising, as I am just below that.) Lymph fluids and intercellular fluid travels by gravity - which means it all wants to go downward, and sometimes tissues don't get the drainage and lubrication they need, causing fluid retention or scarring/adhesions.  Bouncing on a rebounder induces weightlessness which will promote better circulation of fluids between cells and better circulatory removal of wastes. This can have a MAJOR impact on scar tissue.  Seems too silly to work, but it really does.
